thread.title: At World Trade Center Memorial, a Bombing Is Forgotten
thread.title_full: At World Trade Center Memorial, a Bombing Is Forgotten

author: RUTH BASHINSKY
title: At World Trade Center Memorial, a Bombing Is Forgotten
text:
At World Trade Center Memorial, a Bombing Is Forgotten The New York Times 3 hrs ago By RUTH BASHINSKY © Tess Mayer for The New York Times The 9/11 Memorial. Many visitors did not know about the 1993 attack at the World Trade Center. They came to Lower Manhattan from around the world to visit the 9/11 Memorial on an unseasonably warm winter day. They came to see where it had happened — where terrorists had crashed two jetliners into the World Trade Center towers, destroying them in horrific plumes of ash, flames and pulverized concrete.
But many did not realize they were also visiting the site of an earlier attack that, while less deadly, presaged an era of terrorism fears in New York City that many believe culminated in September 2001.
Sign Up For the Morning Briefing Newsletter
It has been almost 24 years since the Feb. 26, 1993, World Trade Center bombing that killed six people and injured around 1,000, and many who gathered outside the 9/11 Memorial on Sunday had no knowledge of the attack or the fiery speech of the man — Omar Abdel Rahman — who the authorities believe inspired it.
Mr. Abdel Rahman died on Saturday in a federal prison in North Carolina where he was serving a life sentence for his role in plotting a broad terror campaign in New York that was never carried out.
Kath Jones of Portsmouth, England, who was waiting with her daughter and her friends to get into the memorial, said she did not remember the 1993 bombing. But for her, as it does for so many, Sept. 11 looms large. She was deployed to Afghanistan four times from 2004 to 2014.
“I was a nurse for the Royal Navy and would take care of the Americans and Brits who came to the military hospital,” said Ms. Jones, 46, who recently retired after serving 25 years.
Her daughter, Becky, 21, remembered going to military boarding school when she was 12 because her mother was on active duty. She had never heard of the bombing. “I wasn’t born yet,” she said. “I was born in 1996.”
Lisa Morrison, 54, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., only learned of the first World Trade Center attack while learning about Sept. 11. “I was surprised that it happened,” she said.
© Tess Mayer for The New York Times Kath Jones, left, and her daughter, Becky, visited the 9/11 Memorial on Sunday. “I wasn’t born yet,” Becky said of the 1993 attack. “I was born in 1996.” Ravi Singh traveled from his home in New Jersey to see the memorial with his wife and another couple. He did not recall the events of February 1993 — the bombing, followed by the frenzied rush to catch the plotters.
“My children were much younger,” said Mr. Singh, who is self-employed. Mr. Singh, however, had heard the name Omar Abdel Rahman and described him as the “blind sheikh.”
But for some at the memorial on Sunday, the first World Trade Center attack remained a searing memory.
Lindsay Buckley and her husband, Brian, of North Carolina, remembered it well.
“I was very young when that happened,” said Ms. Buckley, 38, who grew up in Texas. “It was my first experience with Islamophobia. My dad called it radical terrorism. I don’t particularly subscribe to that point of view.”
Mr. Buckley remembered how upset his parents were. “The TV was always on,” he said. “They were news junkies.”
His parents emigrated to the United States from Ireland. “We grew up in Dublin, and there were the Troubles,” he said. “Bombs going off in a city is reminiscent of a bombing going off at home.”
